title: How to Secure a Bookcase to a Wall

steps.headline: Use a stud finder to mark where the wall studs are.
steps.description: Take a magnetic stud locator and place it on the wall where you plan to secure the bookcase. After you find where the studs are, mark their locations with a pencil. This ensures that the straps will be secured into the wall frame once they’re installed. Make sure the stud markings are 16 inches (41 cm) apart if you don’t have a stud finder on hand. This method works best on metal and wooden wall frames.

steps.headline: Mark your bookshelf’s height onto the wall.
steps.description: Use a tape measure to figure out how tall your bookcase is. Once you have a measurement on hand, mark your bookcase’s height onto the wall. Make sure that this marking is in line with the location of the wall studs since that’s where you’ll be drilling later. Push the bookcase back far enough so you enough room to comfortably mark the measurements on the wall.

steps.headline: Make 2 marks 8 inches (20 cm) below the first marking.
steps.description: Measure 8 inches (20 cm) below the bookshelf height and create 2 additional marks to secure the brackets. Consult the directions on the anchor straps to see how far apart they need to be. The exact placement of your wall straps may differ depending on the manufacturer. Consult the installation guide to make sure that you’re marking the correct places.

steps.headline: Drill holes into the areas marked for the brackets.
steps.description: Create 2 entry holes in the wall to make the bracket installation process simpler. Since you’re drilling into the wall frame, it’s important to make sure that the installation is as secure as possible. Having these entry holes ready beforehand saves you time and effort later on. Check to see that your drill bit matches the size of the screws you’re using to install the bracket. Read over the anchor bracket’s packaging and see what kinds of screws are needed to secure them into place. Chances are, you’ll need a combination of 1 in (2.5 cm) screws as well as screws that are less than 0.5 in (1.3 cm) long.

steps.headline: Secure the metal bracket anchors into place.
steps.description: Align the metal bracket on a 1 in (2.5 cm) long screw and drill it slowly into the wall. Make sure that the bracket is centered along the entry hole before screwing it into the wall frame. Both of these anchors have to be sturdy before you attach the bookcase brackets, or else the straps won’t hold.

steps.headline: Screw 2 brackets into the bookcase’s top trim.
steps.description: Find the top edge along the back of the bookcase where the wood is thickest. Measure this edge, and attach the remaining 2 anchor brackets along this part. Like the wall anchors, place the metal piece on the 0.5 in (1.3 cm) long screw and gently guide them both into the bookcase with the drill. It doesn’t matter if the brackets are an equal distance away from each other since the straps won’t be visible to the naked eye. Make sure you don’t drill the bookcase bracket into the back of a shelf, as this won’t be as secure.

steps.headline: Attach the straps to secure the bookcase to the wall.
steps.description: Take the straps attached to the brackets and loop them together. This movement should be similar to tying a belt. Use the extra slack on the straps to tighten them, and push the bookcase against the wall as you do so. The straps should automatically be attached to the anchor brackets. If not, check the installation guide to see how you should attach the straps to the anchor brackets. Ask someone to help you tighten the straps and move the bookcase into place. Depending on the manufacturer, the straps might have a different tightening mechanism.

methods.name: Anchoring a Corner Bookcase with Brackets

steps.headline: Measure the width of your bookcases.
steps.description: Take note of how wide your central bookcase and side shelving pieces are. Depending on the manufacturer, there’s a good chance that your corner bookcase has at least 3 shelving components. In order to set this furniture up properly, you need to have the right measurements on hand.

steps.headline: Align 2 wall brackets on top of the bookshelf.
steps.description: Take 2 L-shaped brackets and position them so they’re equal distances away from the edge of the bookcase. They don’t have to be exactly even, but measuring the distance between the brackets will make the finished installation look more professional. If your bookcase is designed to specifically fit into a corner, align the metal brackets so they’re both attached to a different wall. If you’re buying a corner shelf from a furniture company, there’s a good chance that the screws and brackets you need will come in the packaging. If not, purchase a variety of 1 inch (2.5 cm) or longer screws in addition to shorter 0.5 in (13 mm) screws. Ask a hardware store associate for clarification if you need any assistance while buying these materials.

steps.headline: Position a V-shaped bracket beneath the left side of the bookcase.
steps.description: Tilt the piece of furniture at an angle so that the foot of the bookcase that’s closest to the corner is in the air. Take a metal bracket and slide it under the foot of the bookcase that’s closest to the wall’s corner. Do not move the bookcase and position the bracket by yourself—instead, have someone tilt the bookcase as you secure the V-shaped metal piece into place. This bracket has a slightly raised edge that helps keep it in place along the foot of the bookcase.

steps.headline: Drill 2 screws and nuts into each upper bracket.
steps.description: Take a screw that’s at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) long and drill it into the portion of the bracket that’s touching the wall. If the manufacturer provides it, slide a thin metal nut onto the screw before you drill it into place. Repeat this process to attach a shorter screw into the portion of the bracket that’s touching the bookcase. Check the manufacturer’s instructions for the specific screw size you should use. Depending on the size and complexity of your bookcase, it may differ.

steps.headline: Repeat this process on the right side of the bookcase.
steps.description: Align the right bookcase so that it’s a mirror image of the left bookcase. Position a V-shaped bracket beneath the left bookcase, then use the same screws and nuts to secure 2 L-shaped brackets to the top of the bookcase. Make sure that the central component can snugly fit between the 2 bookcases you’ve already installed.

steps.headline: Connect all 3 bookcases with 2 more V-shaped brackets.
steps.description: Get another person to help you slide the central bookcase in between the installed components. Since there’s a gap between the wall corner and the back of the central bookcase, this component will be held in place by the adjoining V-shaped brackets that attach it to the side bookcases from the top and bottom. Drill 2 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) rounded screws into these brackets to hold them in place. Use a stepladder to reach and secure the brackets into place, if necessary.
